_header: He that whilom did his diligence
Bibliographic Ghosts: Cambridge UK, St John’s College K.30 (233), f. 94; Oxford, Bodleian Library e Musaeo 181 (SC 3556) ; London, British Library Harley 2202: see 4289.
_description: John Lydgate, Fall of Princes — 36365 lines in the complete text, in rhyme royal and 8-line stanzas (ababbcbc)

BodArcSelB10.Note:
Copied from 
            Lydgate, John, The prouerbes of Lydgate, de Worde, [1510?] ; extract only.

BodAsh59.First Lines:
Rome Remembre of þy fundacounAnd of what people þou toke
                    þy gynnyngþy bylding gane of fals discencounOf slaughtre of
                    murdre and of gret robbing…
BodAsh59.Last Lines:
…Now was she mannysshe now was she ffemynyneNow coude she
                    rayne now koude she falsly shyne
BodAsh59.Note:
29 stanzas on folios 13-16v, 11 stanzas of folios
                        28v-29v, 31 lines on folio 59, and 9 stanzas on folio
                    183.
BodAsh59.Attributed Author:
Lenvoye by Lidegate (f. 15); Tragedye made by Lidegate (RT, f.
                    59)
BodAsh59.Attributed Title:
þe Tragedye of Rome by Lidegate (f. 13); Here foloweþe a balade
                    by a gode Clerk made þat is cleped presbiter Johannes to advertyse þe
                    hye prynces þat haue þe power of þe pepul to govrne hem &
                    counsel and vertue (f. 28)

Bod263.First Lines:
HE that whilom dede his dilligence The book of bochas in frensh to
                    translate…
Bod263.Last Lines:
…Now on the wheel now set in louh degre Who wil encrece bi
                    vertu must Ascende
Bod263.Editions:
Bergen,  Henry,
                        ed.  
             Lydgate’s Fall of Princes.
         Washington, D.C.: Carnegie Institute, 1923. 
Bergen,  Henry,
                        ed.  
             Lydgate’s Fall of Princes.
             4 vols. 
             EETS
         e.s. 121-24 (1924-27); repr. 1967: cxxi.
Hammond,  Eleanor Prescott. 
             “Poet and Patron in the Fall of Princes: Lydgate and Humphrey of
                Gloucester.” 
             Anglia
         38 (1914): 121-36: 129-34 (Envoy to Bk III, ch. 8).
Gray,  Douglas. 
             The Oxford Book of Late Medieval Verse and Prose.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1985: 64-8 (‘Complaint of Canace’ only).

BodDig181.First Lines:
All though so be in euery maner Ageffolkis been dyuers of
                    Condicions…
BodDig181.Last Lines:
…Bothe circumspect not hasty but prudentAnd yeuyth no credence
                    without auysement
BodDig181.Attributed Title:
Where Bochas repreuyth hem þat yeue hasti credence to euery report or
                    tale (f. 52)

BodHat2.First Lines:
HE that whilom did his diligenceThe book of Bochas in
                    frenssh…
BodHat2.Last Lines:
…Now on the wheel now set in lowe degreWho list encrece be
                    vertu must ascende

BodeMus1.First Lines:
He that sumtyme dude his diligensThe boke of bochas in englissh to
                    translate…
BodeMus1.Last Lines:
…The ffame arose hou al that regiounBy hur falcenesse stood at
                    dyuysioun

BodRawC448.First Lines:
HE that some tyme dyd his delygenceThe boke of Bochas in frensh to
                    translate…
BodRawC448.Last Lines:
…Nowe on the wheell now sett In low[ ]Who will encrese by
                    vertu must assen[ ]
BodRawC448.Note:
Preceded by table of contents; only a fragment of f. 185 survives; at
                    the end: ‘ffinis totius libri’.

OxfBal329.First Lines:
…SOdeyn departyng oute of þis feliciteIn to miserie
                    & mortal heuenesse…
OxfBal329.Last Lines:
…Now oon þe whele now sette in louh degreWho wyll encrese
                    bi vertu most ascende

OxfCCC242.First Lines:
…It is remembrid of his worthynesWhil þat he was
                    flouryng in yong age…
OxfCCC242.Last Lines:
…his victories his Marciall RenounsRadde & Remembrid in
                    dyuers Regiouns
OxfCCC242.Note: Missing one leaf at beginning and imperfect at end.

CamFitzMc182.First Lines:
Princes considere in euery ageffolkis bene diuerse of there
                    condicionTo pley and turne and change in þer corage¡it is
                    þere none to myne opinion…
CamFitzMc182.Last Lines:
…Holde vp the balaunce of dome in youre manhedeThat lawe in
                    Iuges be not coruptid with mede
CamFitzMc182.Note:
Extract from Lydgate’s Fall of Princes14 x RR, preceding
                    text ends on f. 51, ‘Explicit’ and this begins with decorated
                    initial, so treated as separate work.

CamMagPep2011.First Lines:
O noble prynces off hige discressiounSithe in this worlde ys none
                    abydynge…
CamMagPep2011.Last Lines:
…lyke to Syrennes with voyse MelodiousAnoynt youre Eres to
                    make you lecherous
CamMagPep2011.Note:
Book II, lines 4586-4592 and Book III, 1569-1582 and
                    1590-1638.
CamMagPep2011.Attributed Title:
A lenvoye to all prynces that be disposed to be lecherous (f. 77); Explicit
                    desolacioun of Rome (f. 78)
CamMagPep2011.Editions:
Edwards,  A. S. G. 
             “Lydgate’s “Fall of Princes”: unrecorded
                readings.” 
             Notes & Queries
         16 (1969): 170-1. 
Edwards,  A. S. G. 
             “Selections from Lydgate’s Fall of Princes: a Checklist.” 
             The Library
         5th ser. vol. 26 (1971): 337-42.

CamTCC600.First Lines:
Þis Tragedye gyveþe a gret warnyngBy clere ensaumples of
                    manyfolde resoun…
CamTCC600.Last Lines:
…Lyche to Syryns with voyce melodyousBlaundisshe youre erys to
                    make yowe lechcherous
CamTCC600.Attributed Title:
Loo here my lordes begynneþe a balade ryal nowe late made by daun
                    Johan Lydegate þe Munk of Bury ymagyned by him with in þe tyme of his
                    translacion of Bocas by þe commandement of my lord of Gloucestre (p. 368);
                    Balade of Bochas (RT).

BLAdd21410.First Lines:
[B]e discending of a sodeine leueneWher throuȝ here place was
                    into asshes brent…
BLAdd21410.Last Lines:
…Now on the whell now sette in lowe degreWho list encres by
                    vertu must ascende
BLAdd21410.Note: Begins imperfectly at Bk. I, ch. 8, stanza 63.

BLAdd29729.First Lines:
this tragedye gyueth a gret varnyngeby clere ensampelles of
                    manyfould resoun…
BLAdd29729.Last Lines:
…lych ten syryns with voyce melodyusblaundishe your erys to
                    make youe lecherus
BLAdd29729.Attributed Author: dane Iohn lydgate þe munke of bury (f. 169v)
BLAdd29729.Attributed Title:
Loo here my lordes begynneth a balade ryall now late made by dane Iohn
                    lydgate þe munke of bury ymagyned by him with in þe tyme of his
                    translation of bocus by þe commaundement of my lord of glocester (f.
                        169v)

BLAdd39659.First Lines:
He that whilom dide his dilligenceThe book of Bochas in frenssh to
                    translate…
BLAdd39659.Last Lines:
…Go forth I praye excuse thi self & meWho lovith most
                    vertu hihest shal ascende
BLAdd39659.Attributed Title:
Incipit Liber Bochasii casu Principum (f. 1, rubricated). Final
                    stanza of the ‘Wordis of the translatour vnto his book’ is
                    missing.

BLHar172.First Lines:
…[A]lle thow o be in euery manyer age[ ]folkys [ ] dyuerse of
                    condicions…
BLHar172.Last Lines:
…Of corages in highe or lowe degreSo ys ther trewly a grete
                    dyuersitee…
BLHar172.Note: Fragment, a single leaf written both sides.

BLHar367.First Lines:
Rome Remember of thy foundationand of what people thow toke
                    begenninge…
BLHar367.Last Lines:
…let the states of theyr birthe honorablevoyde all Rascall and
                    wedden theyr semplable
BLHar367.Note: Written by the hand of John Stow.
BLHar367.Attributed Title: The tragedy of Rome (by scribe, John Stow, f. 83v)

BLHar1245.First Lines: HE that whilom did his diligenceThe booke of of Bochas in french to translate…
BLHar1245.Last Lines: …now on þe whele now sett in louh degrewho wil encres by vertu must ascende
BLHar1245.Attributed Title: Explicit liber Iohannis Bochasii de casu principum (f. 182va)
BLHar1245.Facsimiles:
Digital Facsimile of British Library Harley MS 1245.
         https://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?index=0&ref=Harley_MS_1245.

BLHar1766.First Lines:
This famous werk to putte in RemembraunceThe sodeyn Chaunge tretyng
                    of many Estat…
BLHar1766.Last Lines:
…Now on the wheel now set in lowh degreWhoo wyl encrese by
                    vertu must ascende Explicit
BLHar1766.Editions:
Sisam,  Celia,  and  Kenneth Sisam, eds.  
             The Oxford Book of Medieval English Verse.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1970: 399-402.

BLHar2251.First Lines:
SOdeyne departyng from this felicyteIn to myserye and mortal
                    hevynesse… [f. 81v]
BVt whan that Bochas cast his booke asideSole in his studye as he
                    sat writynge… [f. 126]
O thow pouert meke hymble and debonayreWhiche ay that keepest the
                    lawes of nature… [f. 143v]
BLHar2251.Last Lines:
…To sende yow myght grace and prosperteEuere in vertu to
                    encrese and ascende [f. 125v]
…To grucche or froune whan the trawth is lernedThough ther be
                    som that be wele gouerned [f. 143]
…There is more trust in vertuous symplesseThanne in presumyng
                    in vicious false Richesse [f. 145v]

BLHar2255.First Lines:
Myn auctour now Bochas writ no lenger processeOf Iulius deth
                    compleynyng but a whyle…
BLHar2255.Last Lines:
…lyk a myrour of ContemplaciounTo folk that cast them in vertu
                    to be stable

BLHar3486.First Lines:
He þat whilome didd his diligeunceÞe boke of bochas in
                    fraynshe to translate…
BLHar3486.Last Lines:
…In þat tym arblast nouther bowParaventur þat tym
                    bot littil know

BLHar4011.First Lines:
This tragedy geuyth us ful warnynghow many a prince for þer
                    foule leuyng…
BLHar4011.Last Lines:
…lat this conceyte ay yn your hertis myneBy ensample of Rome
                    how al goþe to Ruyne
BLHar4011.Note:
Extract, containing only the Envoy to Humphrey Duke of Gloucester and
                    description of the ‘desolacyon’ of Rome, in that order.
BLHar4011.Attributed Author:
Quod Willelmus Woodeward (rubric after last line, f.
                    2vb)
BLHar4011.Attributed Title:
Lenvoye to humfray late Duke of Glowceter whome god assoyle (rubric, f.
                        1vb); The desolacyon of Rome made by lydgate in Balade wise
                    (rubric, f. 2ra)

BLHar4197.First Lines: He that whilom ded hys diligenceThe booke of Bokas in frensh to translate…
BLHar4197.Last Lines: …and Tragedyes in especiallbe rad & song all feestys funerall…
BLHar4197.Note: A few lines wanting at end.

BLHar4203.First Lines: HE that whilom did his diligenceThe boke of Bochas in ffrensh to translate…
BLHar4203.Last Lines: …Now on the wheel now set in lowe degreWho lyst encresse be vertu must ascende
BLHar4203.Note: Below last line, “Explicit liber totum” and “Nunc finem feci da michi quod merui” (f. 181vb)
BLHar4203.Attributed Author: Sy fyne le liure de John Bochas des cas des nobles hommes & femmes translate du latyn en francoys par laurence du premyer fait. Clerk de la diose de troye & fut compile ceste translacion le xxv-e Iour dauril Mil CCCC & ix et cest assauoyr le lundy apres pasques closes (f. 181v below first column, rubric)
BLHar4203.Attributed Title: le liure de John Bochas des cas des nobles hommes (f. 181v below first column, rubric)

BLLan699.First Lines:
WAs evir prince myht hym silff assureOff fortune the sauour to
                    restreyne…
BLLan699.Last Lines:
…There hih noblesse whil attemperaunceWith hir thre sustren
                    hadde ther gouernaunce
BLLan699.Note:
Extracts from The Fall of Princes about King Arthur, Constantine,
                    and the ‘golden worlde’.

BLRoy18Div.First Lines:
HE that whilom dede his diligenceThe book of bochas in french to
                    translate…
BLRoy18Div.Last Lines:
…Now on the wheel now sett in low degreWho will encrese bi
                    vertu most ascende
BLRoy18Div.Note:
Lines 372-420 on the Duke of Gloucester from this MS (f. 4) formerly
                        711; treated as is separate in editions listed
                    below. Decorated with ornate borders and coat of arms.
BLRoy18Div.Editions:
Turner,  Sharon. 
             History of England from the Norman Conquest to the Accession of Edward
                the First…from the Accession of Edward the First to the Death of Henry
                V…comprising the Reigns of Henry VI, Edward IV, Edward V, Richard III and
                Henry VII.
         3 vols. London: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme and Brown, 1814, 1815, 1823;
            many editions: 3.155 (lines 372-420 only).
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             The Babees Book, etc.
EETS
         o.s. 32 (1868); rev. ed.  Early English Meals and
                Manners London: Trübner, 1876; repr. 1973: lxxxv-vi (rev.ed.; lines 372-420 only).
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             The Boke of Norture, by John Russell, ab. 1460-70 A.D.
Roxburghe Club
         87. Bungay: J. Childs and Son, 1867: xv-xvi (lines 372-420 only).

BLRoy18Dv.Editions:
Hammond,  Eleanor Prescott. 
             “Poet and Patron in the Fall of Princes: Lydgate and Humphrey of
                Gloucester.” 
             Anglia
         38 (1914): 121-36: 129-34 (Prologue to Bk III).

Belvoir.First Lines:
HE that whilom did his diligenceThe boke of Bochas in frensche to
                    translate…
Belvoir.Last Lines:
…Now on the wheel nowe set in lowe degreWho will encrece b[ ]
                    must ascende

NLSGaelic37.First Lines:
…Quhen sche It knew sche maid no taryingbot Plane and hole
                    sche gane It to declayr Suche doubil trust þer is in vepingSuche
                    weping wyffis ewill mot þai fair…
NLSGaelic37.Last Lines:
…In sted of blew quhiche stedfast is and clene Sche louit changeus
                    of mony diuerse grene
NLSGaelic37.Note:
Two stanzas rhyme royal extracted from the story of
                    Samsoun.

GULHun5.First Lines:
…As they had of ffortune the maystryHer enchaunted with
                    theire potacions…
GULHun5.Last Lines:
…Now on þe whele now set in lowe degreWho will encrese by
                    vertu most ascende
GULHun5.Attributed Title:
Here endith the Boke of John Bochas of the fall of princes (f.
                        211ra)

Lam256.First Lines:
…Yit of his mercy and beneuolenceWithoute vengeaunce rigour
                    or disdein…
Lam256.Last Lines:
…Now on the whele now set in lowe degreWho will encrece be
                    vertu must Ascende
Lam256.Attributed Author:
ffinis libri Bochasij (f. 179v); ffinis tocius
                        libri / Of your charite pray for the writer of this book (f.
                    180)

RylandsEng2.First Lines:
HE that sumtyme dide his diligenceThe book of Bochas in frenssh to
                    translate…
RylandsEng2.Last Lines:
…Now on the wheel now set on lowe degreWho will encrece by
                    vertue must ascende
RylandsEng2.Note:
Copy text for STC 3175; text ends f. 183rb, then envoy of 5
                    stanzas (183rb-183va), closing of ‘Bochas’, (8
                    stanzas, 183va-184ra), words of the translator (5 stanzas,
                        183vb-184ra) and final envoy (=855).
RylandsEng2.Attributed Title:
Here begynneth the book callyd 1 Bochas descriuyng the falle of Pryncys
                    pryncessys and othir nobles translatid in to Inglissh bi John Ludgate Monke of
                    the Monastery of seynt Edmundes Bury atte commaundemet of the worthi prynce
                    hymfrey duk of Gloucestre begynnyg at Adam & endyng wt kyng John
                    taken prisoner in ffraunce bi Prynce Edward (rubric; f.
                    1ra).

ChicagoUL565.Note: Missing lines 1-65 of Prologue and ends imperfectly.

Chicago333.First Lines:
He þat did some tyme his besi diligenceThe boke of Bokas in
                    frensh to translate…
Chicago333.Note:
Last few leaves damaged by damp, with text in last stanza mostly
                    obliterated.

Plimpton255.First Lines:
…Aftir Narcisus was a tewelle wentAnd to John Bochas declarid
                    had his woe…
Plimpton255.Last Lines:
…Of Andromedus the surfettis shewingThat ye be grace may haue
                    a good endyng…
Plimpton255.Note: Begins imperfectly at Book I, ch. xv, stanza 19.

PierpontM124.First Lines:
HE that whilom did hys diligenceThe booke of Bochas in frenssh to
                    translate…
PierpontM124.Last Lines:
…fortunes wheele by reuoluciondooth oon clymbe vp an other to
                    [ ]
PierpontM124.Note:
Added stanza as colophon, f. 185vb: Noble Prynces [ ]ll
                    all the[ ] thingespaised of res[ ] of [ ]yis þre and
                    see……maugre fortunes mutabilitieYe shall to god [
                    ].

PierpontM4.First Lines:
Noble prynces of highe discressiounSith in this worlde ys none
                    abydynge…
PierpontM4.Last Lines:
…Hathe thurgh false lustes aforne manasydBy sleight of women
                    derked and defacyd
PierpontM4.Note:
Envoy only, with heading, ‘A lenvoye to all prynces and lordes /
                    that be dysposyd to be lecherous’ (f. 74); 11 x RR.

PhilFree314.First Lines:
…For they were gone out so fer a straySo disseuerid he ne
                    coude hem mere…
PhilFree314.Last Lines:
…That I neuer by non conspiracieWrouȝt or compassed agein
                    his regalie…
PhilFree314.Note:
Part of New York,  Columbia University Library Plimpton 255 = folio 42; begins Book II, second
                    verseone leaf only; 32 stanzas RR.

PhilRos43916.First Lines:
HE that whilom did his diligenceThe book of Bochas in french to
                    translatt…
PhilRos43916.Last Lines:
…Whan two tyrauntis be bothe of one assentWith [multitude?] to
                    accomplissh there entent
PhilRos43916.Note: Ends imperfectly at bottom of page.

PULGar139.First Lines:
HE þat whilom dide his diligenceThe boke of Bochas in frensh
                    to translate…
PULGar139.Last Lines:
…Now on þe whele now set in lowe degreWho will encres be
                    vertu most ascende
PULGar139.Note:
Pages numbered 1-419; seems by content to end incomplete, but space left
                    for further text on this column and next, and blank page that
                    follows.

PULTayM2.First Lines:
HE that whil [ ] his diligenc[e]The book of Bochas in frensch to
                    translateOut of latyn he callid was laurence…
PULTayM2.Last Lines:
…Now on þe whele nowe sete on low degreWho will encresse
                    by vertu mooste ascende

HunHM268.First Lines:
…This sciences were called liberalOnly of fredam ffraunchise
                    & liberte…
HunHM268.Last Lines:
…Of Intrusioun began first this quarelleAgeyn Romeyns when
                    that he gan rebelle…
HunHM268.Note:
Begins imperfectly at 1.4257 due to four quires missing at front of
                    volume; and missing several further quires and folia; Second missing quire at
                    front probably to be identified as London,  British Library Sloane 2452 (see Edwards (1972)
XEdwards,  A. S. G. 
             “The Huntington Fall of Princes and Sloane 2452.” 
             Manuscripta
         16 (1972): 37-40).

Urbana84.First Lines:
…And to prynces for they be stableffor to come ful faste for
                    alle grete astate…
Urbana84.Last Lines:
…With mortal suerde in nature repreuableageyne þe child
                    ys ofte seyne vengable…

McGill143.Last Lines: …Be rad and songe at feestys fvneral…
McGill143.Note:
Fragment: four non-consecutive folios from a single MS copy: Book V,
                    lines 799-882; Book VII, lines 355-522; Book IX, lines 2434-2587; Book IX, lines
                    3225-3449; described Edwards (1974)
XEdwards,  A. S. G. 
             “The McGill Fragment of Lydgate’s ‘Fall of
                Princes’.” 
             Scriptorium
         28 (1974): 75-7, 75-77.

TokyoTak30.First Lines:
HE that whilom did his diligenceThe book of Bochas in frensh to
                    translate…
TokyoTak30.Last Lines:
…ffor ther Princes supprised were with deedeThrouȝ lak of
                    vitaill in that gret nede

TokyoTak40.First Lines:
…Thys seyde Bochas auctoure of thys bookeWhych of storyes has
                    grete intelligenceSom he leffte and some he tookeSuch as he leffte was
                    of no neclygence…
TokyoTak40.Last Lines:
…By holde of fortune the mutabiliteHow suddenly she made hem
                    to discende[ ] that ys written to oure doctryne

TokyoTak78.First Lines:
…Touching þis mordre odius forto herewhan þt
                    oropastes ocupied in dedeþe croune of perse þe stori doþ vs
                    lereTher was a prince ful notable & entere…
TokyoTak78.Last Lines:
…And forto put hem more in assuranceTo haue victorie
                    þuruȝ þer heiȝ renovn…

TokyoTak79.First Lines:
…PRinces Princessis seeth hou deceptorieBen all this worldli
                    reuolucions…

Sotheby1976.Note: A copy made in 1817 by Philip Absolom.
